metadata.title: Facet Joint Pathology
description: Facet joints(1) –Comprise the posterolateral articulation of adjacent spinal vertebrae –Vary in orientation depending on the level of the spine –Fall under the category of synovial joints with hyaline cartilage overlying subchondral bone. Each joint contains a joint capsule and a synovial membrane –Also called zygapophyseal joints(2)

Types of facet joint pathology –Sprain –Trauma to the capsule due to fracture or dislocation(3) –Degenerative joint disease/osteoarthritis (OA)(1) -Equally affects males and females(4) -OA diagnoses increase in prevalence with increased age -Occurs most commonly between L4-L5  and in facet joints that orient more sagittally –Rheumatoid arthritis(1) –Impingement(1) -Typically caused by synovial cysts, which can lead to spinal stenosis or radiculopathy -Facet joint degeneration can lead to impingement of surrounding neural structures
Prevalence of facet joint pathology has been estimated to be between 15% and 45% in patients with chronic low back pain (1)
In patients with nonspecific chronic low back pain, facet joints are estimated to be the origin in 27–40%  of cases(1)
Cervical facet joint syndrome has a prevalence rate of 29% to 60% following whiplash injuries(4)

In the lumbar spine pain can be unilateral but is typically axial, with occasional radiation down to the knee(4) –Rarely, pain can radiate into the abdominal or pelvic areas –Radiating pain is “pseudo-radicular”  and is not associated with neurological deficits –Radiating pain can mimic sciatic pain but is usually due to osteophytes or synovial cysts

Facet joints have been reported to bear about 25% of total spine compressive loads(2) –To compensate for a pathological intervertebral disc, load on the facet joints can almost double –Abnormal loading can lead to OA of the facet joint

ICD-10 codes.M24.8: other specific joint derangements, not elsewhere classified

optional.base: subclassification to indicate site of involvement for M53 and M54

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified

Presentation/signs and symptoms –Symptoms tend to be nonspecific and are often misdiagnosed, misunderstood, or improperly treated(1) –Facet joint syndrome (lumbar spine) -Pain: pain does not typically radiate beyond the knee (1,5) -Sense of achiness, which may radiate into the proximal lower extremity(5) -Pain with axial extension and rotation(5) -Patient may complain of a deep and aching sensation on one or both sides of the spine(6) –Facet joint syndrome (cervical spine) -Pain in the cervical region -Pain may be felt in the shoulder but does not typically go beyond the elbow joint –Patients with facet joint syndrome may have tenderness over the facet joint or transverse process(5) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
presentation signs and symptoms: –Symptoms tend to be nonspecific and are often misdiagnosed, misunderstood, or improperly treated(1) –Facet joint syndrome (lumbar spine) -Pain: pain does not typically radiate beyond the knee (1,5) -Sense of achiness, which may radiate into the proximal lower extremity(5) -Pain with axial extension and rotation(5) -Patient may complain of a deep and aching sensation on one or both sides of the spine(6) –Facet joint syndrome (cervical spine) -Pain in the cervical region -Pain may be felt in the shoulder but does not typically go beyond the elbow joint –Patients with facet joint syndrome may have tenderness over the facet joint or transverse process(5) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Degeneration of the spine, also known as spondylosis(1,4)
Facet joint degeneration is correlated with degeneration of the intervertebral disc(1)
Trauma due to injury or sporting activities(4)
Ankylosing spondylitis and rheumatoid arthritis are inflammatory conditions that can contribute to inflammation of thesynovium(4)
Subluxation of the facet joint due to spondylolisthesis can lead to facet joint disease(4)
Whiplash injury can induce synovitis of the facet joint, leading to neck pain and limited ROM of the neck(7)
pathogenesis: Potential underlying mechanisms of facet joint syndrome–Facet joint tropism is defined as an asymmetry between the right and left facet joint of a spinal segment,in whichone joint has a more sagittal orientation compared to the other joint. Facet joint tropism can lead to disc herniation orspondylolisthesis(1)–The lower lumbar facet joints tend to be the focus for surgical and therapeutic treatment compared to the rest of the spine.Research shows that the lower lumbar facet joints carry the most load and are more susceptible to disc degeneration(2)–Disc degeneration in the lumbar region can lead to osteoarthritic-type  alterations in the affected vertebrae.(1,8) The facetjoints make a tripod of support with the intervertebral discs at each spinal level. Degenerative changes in one part of thesystem affect the system as a whole(1)–Authors of cadaveric and imaging studies have concluded that disc degeneration precedes facet degeneration(1)–Facet joint cartilage is not innervated. However, facet joint pain can arise from nociceptors within and surrounding thejoint(5)-Facet joints are well innervated, as are the subchondral bone, synovium, synovial folds, and the joint capsule-Facet joint pathology can secondarily result in reflex muscle spasm of the erector spinae, multifidi, and other paraspinalmuscles(9)–Trauma secondary to acute injury or sporting activities(4)–Synovial inflammation of the facet joint may be exacerbated by rheumatoid arthritis or ankylosing spondylitis(4)–Degenerative changes of facet joints include osteophyte formation, hypertrophy of the articular processes, thinning of thearticular cartilage with erosions and subchondral cyst formation, joint effusion, and hypertrophy or calcification of thejoint capsule and ligamentumflavum(4)
risk factors: Trauma to the musculoskeletal system that is either acute (e.g., a fall) or chronic (e.g., playing rugby) increases the risk ofjoint degeneration in general
Alterations in the structural integrity of the tripod, particularly degeneration of the intervertebral disc, as well as abnormaljoint alignment or loading are implicated as risk factors(1)
A history of performing heavy work before the age of 20 is a risk factor for developing facet joint osteoarthritis(4)
Age–Prevalence of lumbar facet joint pain increases with age in both the cervical and lumbar spines(1,4,10)

overall contraindications precautions: In patients with rheumatoid arthritis, manipulation (or any other forceful movement) of the spine is contraindicated(11)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -What is the reason for referral? -How long has the patient been experiencing current symptoms? -Did a specific event/activity precede the onset of symptoms? Onset of symptoms is insidious in most patients(12)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Chronic facet joint pain may be managed by intraarticular injections, facet joint nerve blocks, and radiofrequency ablation.(1,4,12) The results of systematic reviews of the effectiveness of these treatments are conflicting(12) After obtaining two positive diagnostic blocks, a radiofrequency ablation is commonly performed on the symptomatic spinal level(s)(4) (See Other considerations , below) Improved function and decreased pain have been reported to last 6 to 12 months following radiofrequency ablation Nerves will eventually regenerate but a repeat procedure can be performed when the patient’s pain returns (typically 6 to 12 months) Common management of chronic low back pain includes facet joint injections. However, only about 1 in 10 patients experiences relief of low back pain postinjection(4) The patient may undergo a facet rhizotomy No guidelines are available to support arthrodesis when other treatments fail(4)  Surgery may be indicated for a grade I or II spondylolisthesis. However, it is not a first-line treatment and may not result inpain reduction(4)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Firstline  drug therapy includes acetaminophen, NSAIDs, antidepressants, and muscle relaxants(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Both CT and MRI have been shown to be valid measurements of facet degeneration(5)
Facet OA is a universal finding in patients over 60 years old and occurs in about 60% of patients over 30 years old(2)
Standard MRI generally does not reveal the presence of inflammation in and around the facet joints of the spine;
however, fatsaturation techniques utilized during an MRI may improve detection(1)
Due to the lack of specificity of facet joint OA on imaging, anesthetic blockade using fluoroscopically guided injections has become standard practice(4)
Medial branch blocks are reported to be the most reliable method of diagnosing pain related to facet joint pathology(4)
Diagnostic blocks of lumbar facet joints with bupivacaine are typically used. At least 2 diagnostic injections should be performed to decrease incidence of false positives(4,5)
Additional diagnostic testing may be recommended to rule out other conditions
Isolating the facet joint as the source of pain is difficult, as imaging has been shown to be of low diagnostic validity.
Xray,  CT, and MRI may appear to reveal a diagnosis, but often significant findings are present in both symptomatic and asymptomatic patients(4)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -In lumbar facet joint syndrome, lumbar hyperextension and extension generally aggravate the patient’s symptoms -Forward flexion may ease symptoms in individuals experiencing pain originating from lumbar facet joints(5) -Pain aggravated by standing and ameliorated by sitting or flexing the spine is common(5)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Localized unilateral pain and pain not radiating past the knee are indicative of lumbar facet joint syndrome
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). In general, are symptoms getting worse, better, or staying the same?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). Utilize the Oswestry Low Back Disability Questionnaire for the lumbar spine and the Neck Disability Index for the cervical spine
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Morning pain and stiffness may be reported(4)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Where applicable, inquire about sleeping position and number and firmness of pillows used
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, radicular pain, neurogenic claudication)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document the presence of any respiratory compromise Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Does the patient have a history of arthritis in other joints?  Has the patient ever had a similar episode of pain?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and other orthopedic disorders. Psychological comorbidity has been reported to increase pain severity and healing time.(5) Comorbidities such as diabetes can affect medial branch sensory perception during diagnosis of facet joint pain(8)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? What is the patient’s occupation?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What functional limitations does the patient report?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  The information listed below is an overview and meant only to serve as a guide. The clinician is advised to modify/supplement the examination process as indicated by patient symptoms and reason for referral
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document the patient’s height and weight and calculate BMI. Measure for leg-length discrepancy as indicated
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient currently utilize any assistive or adaptive devices? Are ambulatory assistive devices appropriately measured and correctly used?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Complete a balance assessment using a standardized assessment such as the Berg Balance Scale
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Complete a gait assessment; document the presence of any deviations –Measure preferred and maximum gait speed using the 10-meter walk test (10MWT) –If spondylolisthesis is present, the patient may appear to have a myopathic (waddling) gait (13) Joint integrity and mobility  (5) –Initially, the patient may present with facet joint hypermobility –Later, mobility within the injured facet joints becomes restricted –Kemp’s sign may be positive (lumbar extension, side bending, and axial rotation toward symptomatic side)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Complete a thorough strength assessment using manual muscle testing (MMT) –Generally, the patient will have difficulty with trunk extension, as extension aggravates symptoms(5)
observation inspection palpation includi: Palpate the spine and surrounding musculature; note deviations
Pain typically is aggravated by palpation of the paraspinal muscles(8)
Taut and tender fibers over inferior articular process and facet joint of the involved segment (usually L4)(14)
Palpable hypertonicity of superficial and deep paraspinal musculature(14)

Spondylolisthesis(1) -Occurs as a subluxation of the facet joints in the sagittal plane -Mostly seen at L4-L5  in older populations and at L5-S1  in younger populations -Caused by OA, congenital abnormalities, isthmic spondylolisthesis, or acute or stress-related fractures
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –The patient will likely present with postural deviations;(13) complete a postural assessment, noting any atypical findings (e.g., scoliosis, leg-length discrepancy, pelvic rotation) –Pronounced lumbar lordosis can be indicative of spondylolisthesis(13) –Crouch posture (hip and knee flexion with external rotation of the feet) has been observed during gait in some patients with spondylolisthesis(13)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –ROM of the spine (in the affected area) will be compromised. Clinicians should complete a thorough ROM assessment of the spine –Assess hamstring flexibility(13)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexesObserve ADLs as indicated. Use Barthel Index or FIM for standardized testing
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Complete a sensory assessment as indicated
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Physical examination can suggest, but not confirm, the facet joint(s) as the source of low back pain.(1,4) Maneuvers that stress the facet joints also disturb surrounding structures –The gold standard to diagnosis facet joint as a pain generator is a series of diagnostic medial branch blocks.(4,5,8) SPECT/ CT scans may also be helpful diagnostic tools for physicians prior to selecting treatment modalities(10)(5) -Unilateral or bilateral lumbar paraspinal muscle pain -Pain radiating to above the knee -More lumbar pain than leg pain -Pain worsens with lumbar extension and/or rotation -Pain is alleviated or improved with rest -New lumbar facet sign -Pain with pressure on facet joint or transverse process -Decreased ROM -Positive Kemp’s sign

contraindications precautions: Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves, areas of diminished sensation, poor circulation, or slow-healing wounds
Use caution with patients who are hypertensive, as cold can cause a transient increase in blood pressure; discontinue treatment if there is an elevation in blood pressure
Use caution with patients who are hypersensitive to cold
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Use of cryotherapy with patients who have an aversion to cold may be counterproductive if being used to promote muscle relaxation and decrease pain
Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Electrotherapy  (15) contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Pain, impaired ROM, impaired strength, and reduced mobility
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Referred pain from kidneys, prostate, female pelvic organs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, or abdominal aortic aneurysm When the pain is unilateral – muscle strain, or stress fracture of pars interarticularis Discogenic pain(1) Nerve root impingement(1) Sacroiliac joint pain(1) Synovial chondromatosis(16) –Should be considered when a mass is near a facet joint
prognosis: Conservative intervention (e.g., physical therapy, prescription medication) provides the majority of patients with facet joint syndrome relief from their symptoms(4,8)
Because a common cause of facet joint pathology is degeneration, it is often progressive(3,4)

Facet joint pathology often coexists with spinal disc abnormalities, and can lead to chronic pain.(1,2) The facet joints are estimated to be the primary pain generator for 38% of patients with chronic low back pain(2)
Maintaining a healthy weight and an active lifestyle can improve prognosis(4) ›Referral to other disciplines  (as indicated)
other considerations: Lumbar facet joint syndrome does not seem to be a reliable diagnosis for low back pain, as a specific etiology of back pain is found in only 15% of cases(1)  –Currently available testing for facet joint syndrome has little to no diagnostic validity –History and examination can suggest but not confirm that the facet joint is the source of low back pain

Physical therapy is used to increase functionality and manage pain in patients with low back pain. Physical examination is a useful tool to aid in diagnosis of facet joint syndrome(6) –A general physical exam includes vital signs, ambulation status (assistive device usage, gait pattern), and psychosocial

desired outcomes: Improved functional mobility–FIM–Barthel Index–Oswestry Disability Index–Neck Disability Index
Improve posture, balance, body mechanics, and strength to return to previous activity level–Berg Balance Scale–Specific return to sport assessments

maintenance or prevention: Continue with home program and follow up with physician as indicated
patient education: Spine-health,  “Facet Joint Disorders and Back Pain,” https://www.spine-health.com/conditions/arthritis/facet-joint-disorders-and-back-pain

Orthogate’s “Lumbar Facet Joint Arthritis” webpage, https://www.orthogate.org/patient-education/lumbar-spine/lumbar-facet-joint-arthritis Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
